newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian parties strike agreement on EU.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian parties strike agreement on EU.

text.p: Slovenia will amend its constitution in line with EU requirements by mid-July, allowing parliament to rubber stamp an association agreement with the bloc, Prime Minister Janez Drnovsek said on Friday.
He told a news conference all parliamentary parties, with the exception of the minority Nationalist Party, had agreed to an amendment allowing foreigners to buy real estate.

"(The parties) have agreed to coordinate on joining the European Union (and) change the constitution by July 15," Drnovsek said. "The constitutional change will be followed immediately by ratification of the EU agreement," he continued.

Slovenia signed an association agreement with the EU last year but progress on ratification has been slow. The courts ruled earlier this month that parliament must first change the constitution to enable foreigners to buy land.

Drnovsek said the cross-party agreement would probably be signed on June 24. The signing would be followed by a parliamentary debate on the constitutional changes and six draft laws aimed at protecting Slovenian national interests.

Drnovsek's centre-left Liberal Democrats, which rule in coalition with the conservative People's Party and pensioners' party Desus, need opposition support to ensure the necessary two-thirds parliamentary majority for the amendments.
The coalition government holds 49 seats in the 90-seat legislature. The Nationalist Party has four seats.
The European Commission has said speedy ratification of the association agreement is a precondition for Slovenia to be part of the bloc's first round of eastward expansion.
